objects.name: spreads via links sent in phishing SMSs
prompt the user to install an app
starts communicating with its C&C server
sent the infected device’s IMEI to the C&C
could automatically reply to an SMS and immediately delete it
used a plain-text JSON format to communicate with its C&C
a dynamically generated low-level domain was used as an address
received a set of rules for processing incoming SMSs
sent information about the smartphone to the C&C, including the phone model, number, name of the mobile network operator, versions of the operating system and IMEI
using the AES algorithm to encrypt data communicated between the infected device and the C&C
checks if it is being launched in an emulation environment, and in which country it is being launched
registers with GCM and launches SuperService which tracks if the Trojan has device administrator privileges
performs a privilege check once every second; if unavailable, the Trojan starts requesting them from the user in an infinite loop
If the Trojan detects an attempt to revoke its administrator privileges, it starts periodically switching off the phone screen, trying to stop the user actions
If the privileges are revoked successfully, the Trojan relaunches the cycle of requesting administrator privileges
tracks its own status and relaunches if stopped
attempt to revoke the device administrator privileges, the Trojan tries to intimidate the use
stores information about C&C servers and the data harvested from the infected device in a local SQLite database
registers in the administration panel and receives the information it needs to operate from the C&C
dynamically generated subdomains can also be used
intercepts all incoming SMSs and processes them according to the templates it received from the C&C
puts the phone into silent mode and switches off the screen so the user doesn’t notice that a new SMS has arrived
sends an SMS to the specified phone number with the information it has received from the intercepted message
saves all SMSs to a local database and uploads them to the C&C
sends a list of all the running processes and installed applications to the C&C
send SMS containing specified text to a specified number
revoke device administrator privileges from the app
download APK file from C&C and install it
send text received from C&C to all user contacts
request unique message text for contacts from the address book
contact URL received from C&C using User-Agent value that was also received from C&C or local database
send C&C all SMSs received and sent by user, as stored in phone memory
send all contacts from phone memory to C&C
send information about Trojan’s current status to C&C: whether it has device administrator privileges, which HTML page is currently displayed, whether screen is on or off, etc
write an SMS to the device memory containing the text and sender number sent from C&C
display phishing HTML page for entry of bank card details
display HTML page of the ransomware
display fake HTML page for update
block display of all HTML pages
revoke device administrator privileges from the app
send text “install: [device IMEI]” to phone number from which SMS was sent
stop displaying all blocking HTML page
change C&C address to that specified in the SMS
mimics a legitimate bank form and blocks the device screen until the user enters all the information
ntercepts a message from the bank that contains the last four digits of the bank card connected to the phone number
sends a command to display a fake data entry window to check the four digits
requesting device administrator privileges again in an infinite loop
